repnme.cdata!:
Indonesia - BAPEDAL Development Technical
            Assistance Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Overall, the project outcome was
            satisfactory. The project objectives were mostly met, and,
            substantial strengthening capacity was achieved in key areas
            of the Environmental Impact Management Agency (BAPEDAL).
            However, a certain lack of initiative, and responsibility,
            may prevent the Agency from improving its ability to control
            pollution, and, effectively manage environmental
            adversities. The key lessons learned suggest, primarily,
            that the establishment of the Project Management Office
            (PMO) during preparation, with a continued role through
            implementation, was vital for success. Mainly, and because,
            it was managed by BAPEDAL, the office thus became the link
            among not only the Bank, and the consultants, but most
            importantly, the various potential donors. This contributed,
            not only to strengthen a new agency's capacity, but to
            actually resolve difficult issues which arose during
            implementation. However, a flexible balance in the provision
            of technical assistance (TA), would have been beneficial,
            since most of the TA was delivered upon completion, not in
            an advisory role. Thus, to complement technical components,
            ideally, counterpart managers per TA team should be
            assigned, and project design should include mechanisms for
            TA delivery. This could have fostered that sense of
            ownership, and, responsibility, needed for enhancing
            institutional capacity.

repnme.cdata!:
Indonesia - BAPEDAL Development Technical
            Assistance Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The primary objective of the project is
            to assist the government in implementing the five year
            Environmental Impact Management Agency (BAPEDAL) Development
            Plan, through: a) strengthening the institutional capacity
            and role of BAPEDAL; and b) designing and implementing
            pollution control measures at the central and regional
            levels.  To achieve these objectives, the loan will provide
            funds amounting to US$12 million equivalent to BAPEDAL to
            finance the provision of technical assistance for: i) the
            review of existing laws, regulations and procedures relating
            to pollution control; ii) design and development of
            pollution control systems and procedures; iii) planning,
            establishment, and strengthening of pollution control
            agencies and laboratories at the regional level; iv)
            assistance with recruitment processes, and the design,
            development and initiation of a training program; and v)
            external resource administration, including the preparation
            of proposals for donor financing within the framework of the
            development plan, assistance to the BAPEDAL managers for
            efficient processing and use of consultant services, and
            financial management and accounting services to meet both
            government and donor agency requirements.
